ygData.subject: Now Available: MaestroGenesis Music Evolution Software

Subject: Now Available: MaestroGenesis Music Evolution Software
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=BddThL30RyHJi-HTcvW5QADGQWb4_6jlkMs2cwdeQfh1lp3O1acn

Paul Szerlip, Amy Hoover, and I are pleased to announce our first complete =
public release of MaestroGenesis, which allows the user to interactively ev=
olve accompaniments to any pre-existing MIDI composition.  The software is =
freely available here:

http://maestrogenesis.com/

In this system, NEAT ev=
olves CPPNs that take the pre-existing music, which is called the "scaffold=
," as input, and output an accompaniment for it.  The accompaniment general=
ly sounds plausible because it is a function of the scaffold.  In effect, t=
he software is based on a very simple musical theory that music sounds good=
 if the listener can perceive a functional relationship among the parts.  
=

This theory is interesting in part because of how much it accomplishes all=
 by itself.  In other words, MaestroGenesis has no other musical knowledge =
within it, yet it still produces plausible accompaniments just by exploitin=
g the functional relationship.

You can learn more on how to use the softwa=
re at the docs page, where there is also a tutorial video:

http://eplex.cs=
.ucf.edu/MaestroGenesis/docs

The download page is:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.ed=
u/MaestroGenesis/downloads

For those interested, a fair amount of academic=
 research has gone into this software, and links to all the relevant public=
ations are at:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/MaestroGenesis/relatedresearch

Bes=
t,

ken
